introduction.content: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths [1] . Lung cancer screening (LCS) with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) reduces lung cancer mortality by 20% in comparison with two-dimensional (2D) chest radiography in the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) [2] and by 24% in comparison with no screening in the NELSON trial [3] . However, LCS faces challenges, such as the low screening rate (<10%) [4] , high false-positive rate [5] , sub-optimal workflows due to inadequate patient management [6] , [7] , [8] , [9] , under-utilization of multimodal data [10] , [11] , and particularly, a global shortage of radiologists for providing LCS. Hence, there is an important and immediate need for multidisciplinary efforts to broadly, equitably, and optimally implement LCS for minimized lung cancer mortality [12] . Artificial intelligence (AI) promises to improve the quality and efficiency of LCS significantly. In particular, there is a vast amount of multimodal data accumulated over the past years, including low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) images, patient demographics, smoking history, disease history, family cancer history, pathological results, follow-up data, etc. [2] LCS involves multiple clinical tasks, including lung nodule detection and characterization, Lung-RADS-based patient follow-up management, lung cancer risk estimation, and significant incidental findings such as diagnosis of various pulmonary, cardiovascular, and chest abnormalities. Deep learning methods achieved promising results for LCS-related tasks. For example, a deep learning method was proposed for lung cancer detection and risk estimation with LDCT in an end-to-end manner [13] . Recently, the Sybil model [14] was developed for lung cancer risk prediction using a single LDCT scan. In several studies [15] , [16] , deep learning models were developed for cardiovascular diseases (CVD) risk prediction with LDCT from LCS. Although promising, these LCS-related AI models were developed with relatively small single-modality datasets for individual tasks, limiting their performance and utility in the multitask LCS workflow. Additionally, the training schemes of current lung cancer risk models [13] , [14] require costly bounding box annotations, which makes building large-scale training datasets infeasible. In the fast-evolving AI field, foundation models (FMs) have shown previously unseen abilities to understand diverse data types and execute many tasks in a unified fashion [17] . Large FMs have updated the state-of-the-art (SoTA) performance across a wide range of tasks, such as natural language processing [18] , [19] , [20] , computer vision [21] , [22] , and multimodal understanding [23] , [24] , [25] . Inspired by these breakthroughs, increasing efforts have been made to develop medical foundation models, such as biomedical language models [26] , [27] , [28] , [29] , [30] , [31] , medical vision-language models [32] , [33] , [34] , and generalist medical AI models [35] , [36] , [37] . However, none of the existing FMs can effectively perform a variety of LCS tasks by interpreting the multimodal clinical data associated with LCS, particularly three-dimensional (3D) LDCT scans. This limitation is primarily due to challenges in data curation and model architecture. First, there is a high bar to systematically curate large-scale multimodal multitask datasets obtained in the real-world LCS workflow. Extensive domain-specific expertise and efforts are required to query, preprocess, and align 3D medical images and diverse structured/unstructured text-based clinical data with LCS-related tasks. Second, there is no scalable and adaptable foundation model dedicated to effectively interpreting multimodal LCS data, especially 3D CT images at different scales, and effectively performing diverse LCS-related tasks. Due to the high dimensionality of volumetric CT images, existing efforts only used small 2D/3D convolutional neural networks [38] and small vision Transformer models [39] at affordable computational costs. In this work, we present an integrated and scalable data curation approach to align high-dimensional medical images with other clinical datasets for LCS-related tasks, including 17 LCS workflow-related tasks and 49 data elements. Then, we develop a Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) that perceives multimodal data including 3D CT volumes and various other clinical data, and performs multiple tasks involved in the LCS workflow. Figure 1 illustrates the M3FM architecture, along with its training and inference processes. Extensive experiments show that our M3FM outperforms the previous SoTA models through large-scale multimodal and multitask learning, with the ability to identify informative data elements and adapt to the out-of-distribution task with a small dataset. Fig. 1: Overview of medical multimodal multitask foundation model (M3FM). a M3FM architecture consists of four components: Computed Tomography Vision Transformer (CTViT), Text Transformer, Task Encoder, and Predictors. b Pretraining CTViT on multiscale CT volumes with voxel size-aware masked image modeling. Scale 1, Scale 2, ⋯ , and Scale S denote S different sizes of images. c Pretraining Text Transformer with masked image models, where T1, T2, ⋯ , and T5 denote a sequence of text tokens, T1, T2, and T4 are inputs, T3 and T5 are targets, and MASK is a special token meaning that the input token is masked. d Training the shared M3FM jointly with flexible multimodal and synergistic multitask learning using our distributed task-parallel strategy. Each device focuses on a single task with task-specific inputs, targets, and loss functions. D , N , and R denote the numbers of different devices, tasks, and image regions, respectively. Different tasks may have the same multimodal inputs on devices 1 and 2 and various multimodal or single-modality inputs on devices 2, 3, 4, and 5. e M3FM inference flexibly handles multi-scale CT volumes (indicated by the rectangle boxes in different sizes and colors), clinical data, and multiple tasks. The colors of the CT bounding boxes match those of the questions and the predicted answers. For example, to answer Question 16, M3FM takes the orange region in the CT volume automatically localized using an organ localization model, the corresponding voxel size, and clinical text data as inputs. Questions 17 and 18 are two examples of auxiliary information retrieval tasks for clinical data modeling, which only take the clinical text as input. Question 19 predicts the Lung CT Screening Reporting and Data System (Lung-RADS) from lung nodule descriptions in a radiology report. reticular/... /scar reticular/reticulonodular opacities/honeycombing/fibrosis/scar, where / means or, COVID-19 Coronavirus Disease 2019. sentences.sentence: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths [1].
viewpoints: Lung cancer is currently the leading cause of cancer-related deaths.

sentences.sentence: Lung cancer screening (LCS) with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) reduces lung cancer mortality by 20% in comparison with two-dimensional (2D) chest radiography in the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) [2] and by 24% in comparison with no screening in the NELSON trial [3].

3.1: There are limited data from randomized trials on the effectiveness of volume-based, low-dose CT screening in reducing lung-cancer mortality among male former and current smokers.
3.2: 13,195 men were part of the primary analysis in a trial involving CT screening for lung cancer.
3.3: 2,594 women were part of the subgroup analyses in a trial involving CT screening for lung cancer.
3.4: Participants were randomly assigned to undergo CT screening at T0 (baseline), year 1, year 3, and year 5.5 or no screening.
3.5: Participants in the trial were between the ages of 50 and 74.
3.6: Data on cancer diagnosis, date of death, and cause of death were obtained through linkages with national registries in the Netherlands and Belgium.
3.7: A review committee confirmed lung cancer as the cause of death when possible.
3.8: A minimum follow-up period of 10 years until December 31, 2015, was completed for all participants in the trial.
3.9: Among men, the average adherence to CT screening was 90.0%.
3.10: On average, 9.2% of the screened participants underwent at least one additional CT scan for initially indeterminate results.
3.11: The overall referral rate for suspicious nodules was 2.1%.
3.12: At 10 years of follow-up, the incidence of lung cancer was 5.58 cases per 1000 person-years in the screening group.
3.13: At 10 years of follow-up, the incidence of lung cancer was 4.91 cases per 1000 person-years in the control group.
3.14: At 10 years of follow-up, lung-cancer mortality was 2.50 deaths per 1000 person-years in the screening group.
3.15: At 10 years of follow-up, lung-cancer mortality was 3.30 deaths per 1000 person-years in the control group.
3.16: The cumulative rate ratio for death from lung cancer at 10 years was 0.76 in the screening group compared with the control group.
3.17: The 95% confidence interval for the cumulative rate ratio was 0.61 to 0.94.
3.18: The p-value for the difference in cumulative rate ratio was 0.01.
3.19: The cumulative rate ratio for lung cancer death in the screening group was similar at years 8 and 9.
3.20: Among women, the rate ratio for death from lung cancer at 10 years of follow-up was 0.67.
3.21: The 95% confidence interval for the rate ratio among women was 0.38 to 1.14.
3.22: The rate ratio for lung cancer death among women was 0.41 to 0.52 in years 7 through 9.
3.23: In this trial involving high-risk persons, lung-cancer mortality was significantly lower among those who underwent volume CT screening than among those who underwent no screening.
3.24: There were low rates of follow-up procedures for results suggestive of lung cancer.
3.25: The trial was funded by the Netherlands Organization of Health Research and Development and others.
3.26: The NELSON Netherlands Trial Register number is NL580.

viewpoints: Lung cancer screening with low-dose computed tomography reduces lung cancer mortality by 20% compared to two-dimensional chest radiography in the National Lung Screening Trial.
Lung cancer screening with low-dose computed tomography reduces lung cancer mortality by 24% compared to no screening in the NELSON trial.

sentences.sentence: However, LCS faces challenges, such as the low screening rate (<10%) [4], high false-positive rate [5], sub-optimal workflows due to inadequate patient management [6], [7], [8], [9], under-utilization of multimodal data [10], [11], and particularly, a global shortage of radiologists for providing LCS.

4.1: Annual lung cancer screening (LCS) with low-dose chest computed tomography in older current and former smokers (ie, eligible adults) has been recommended since 2013.
4.2: Annual lung cancer screening with low-dose chest computed tomography has been recommended for older current and former smokers since 2013.
4.3: Older current and former smokers are considered eligible adults for annual lung cancer screening.
4.4: The uptake of annual lung cancer screening with low-dose chest computed tomography has been slow across the United States.
4.5: The uptake of annual lung cancer screening with low-dose chest computed tomography has been variable across different regions of the United States.
4.6: The lung cancer screening rate was estimated at the national level between 2016 and 2018.
4.7: The lung cancer screening rate was estimated at the state level between 2016 and 2018.
4.8: The growth of lung cancer screening rates was estimated at the national level between 2016 and 2018.
4.9: The growth of lung cancer screening rates was estimated at the state level between 2016 and 2018.
4.10: The American College of Radiology's Lung Cancer Screening Registry was used to capture lung cancer screening events.
4.11: Population-based surveys were used to estimate the number of eligible adults for lung cancer screening.
4.12: Population-based surveys were used to estimate lung cancer mortality, also referred to as lung cancer burden.
4.13: The US Census was used to estimate the number of eligible adults for lung cancer screening.
4.14: The US Census was used to estimate lung cancer mortality.
4.15: Cancer registry data was used to estimate the number of eligible adults for lung cancer screening.
4.16: Cancer registry data was used to estimate lung cancer mortality.
4.17: Lung cancer screening rates in eligible adults were used to measure changes by state and year.
4.18: Screening rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals were used to measure changes by state and year.
4.19: The national lung cancer screening rate was steady at 3.3% in 2016 with a 95% confidence interval from 3.3% to 3.7%.
4.20: The national lung cancer screening rate was steady at 3.4% in 2017 with a 95% confidence interval from 3.4% to 3.9%.
4.21: The national lung cancer screening rate increased to 5.0% in 2018 with a 95% confidence interval from 5.0% to 5.7%.
4.22: The screening rate ratio for 2018 compared to 2016 was 1.52 with a 95% confidence interval from 1.51 to 1.62.
4.23: In 2018, several southern states with a high lung cancer burden had relatively low lung cancer screening rates below 4% among eligible adults.
4.24: Mississippi, West Virginia, and Arkansas are examples of southern states with high lung cancer burdens and relatively low lung cancer screening rates.
4.25: Several northeastern states with lower lung cancer burdens had the highest lung cancer screening rates ranging from 12.8% to 15.2% in 2018.
4.26: Massachusetts, Vermont, and New Hampshire are examples of northeastern states with lower lung cancer burdens and the highest lung cancer screening rates.
4.27: Kentucky had the nation's highest lung cancer mortality rate in 2018.
4.28: Kentucky had one of the highest lung cancer screening rates at 13.7% in 2018.
4.29: Fewer than 1 in 20 eligible adults received lung cancer screening nationally.
4.30: The uptake of lung cancer screening varied widely across states.
4.31: Lung cancer screening rates were not aligned with lung cancer burden across states.
4.32: Kentucky supported comprehensive efforts to implement lung cancer screening.
4.33: Kentucky was an exception where lung cancer screening rates aligned with lung cancer burden due to its efforts.

5.1: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US.
5.2: The evidence on screening for lung cancer with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) is being reviewed to inform the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF).
5.3: Sources of data for the review included MEDLINE, Cochrane Library, and trial registries through May 2019.
5.4: The review utilized references, experts, and literature surveillance through November 20, 2020.
5.5: The review included English-language studies on screening with LDCT.
5.6: The review included English-language studies on the accuracy of LDCT.
5.7: The review included English-language studies on risk prediction models.
5.8: The review included English-language studies on treatment for early-stage lung cancer.
5.9: Abstracts underwent dual review for inclusion in the study.
5.10: Full-text articles underwent dual review for inclusion in the study.
5.11: Study quality was assessed through dual review.
5.13: Data were not pooled due to heterogeneity of populations.
5.14: Data were not pooled due to heterogeneity of screening protocols.
5.15: The review examined lung cancer incidence.
5.16: The review examined lung cancer mortality.
5.19: The review examined harms related to lung cancer screening.
5.21: Seven randomized clinical trials (RCTs) with a total sample size of 86,486 evaluated lung cancer screening with LDCT.
5.22: The National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) was one of the largest RCTs with a sample size of 53,454.
5.23: The Nederlands-Leuvens Longkanker Screenings Onderzoek (NELSON) was one of the largest RCTs with a sample size of 15,792.
5.24: Participants in the reviewed studies were more likely to benefit than the general US screening-eligible population.
5.25: Participants' higher likelihood of benefit was based on factors such as life expectancy.
5.26: The NLST found a reduction in lung cancer mortality with 3 rounds of annual LDCT screening compared to chest radiograph.
5.27: The reduction in lung cancer mortality in the NLST was quantified by an incidence rate ratio (IRR) of 0.85 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 0.75-0.96.
5.28: The number needed to screen (NNS) to prevent one lung cancer death in the NLST was 323 over 6.5 years of follow-up.
5.29: The NLST study population consisted of high-risk current and former smokers aged 55 to 74 years.
5.30: The NELSON trial found a reduction in lung cancer mortality with 4 rounds of LDCT screening with increasing intervals compared to no screening.
5.31: The reduction in lung cancer mortality in the NELSON trial was quantified by an IRR of 0.75 with a 95% CI of 0.61-0.90.
5.32: The NNS to prevent one lung cancer death in the NELSON trial was 130 over 10 years of follow-up.
5.33: The NELSON study population consisted of high-risk current and former smokers aged 50 to 74 years.
5.34: Harms of screening with LDCT included radiation-induced cancer.
5.35: Harms of screening with LDCT included false-positive results leading to unnecessary tests.
5.36: Harms of screening with LDCT included false-positive results leading to invasive procedures.
5.37: Harms of screening with LDCT included overdiagnosis.
5.38: Harms of screening with LDCT included incidental findings.
5.39: Harms of screening with LDCT included increases in distress.
5.40: For every 1000 persons screened in the NLST, false-positive results led to 17 invasive procedures.
5.41: The number needed to harm (NNH) for invasive procedures due to false-positive results in the NLST was 59.
5.42: Fewer than 1 person per 1000 screened in the NLST had a major complication due to LDCT screening.
5.43: Estimates of overdiagnosis in the reviewed studies varied from 0% to 67%.
5.44: Incidental findings were common in LDCT screening studies.
5.45: Estimates of the occurrence of incidental findings varied from 4.4% to 40.7% of persons screened.
5.46: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT can reduce lung cancer mortality.
5.47: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT causes false-positive results leading to unnecessary tests.
5.48: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT causes false-positive results leading to invasive procedures.
5.49: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT causes overdiagnosis.
5.50: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT results in incidental findings.
5.51: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT increases distress.
5.52: Screening high-risk persons with LDCT rarely causes radiation-induced cancers.
5.53: Most of the studies reviewed did not use current nodule evaluation protocols.
5.54: Current nodule evaluation protocols might reduce false-positive results in LDCT screening.
5.55: Current nodule evaluation protocols might reduce invasive procedures for false-positive results in LDCT screening.

7.1: Adherence to follow-up lung cancer screening in real-world settings is inadequate.
7.2: Patient understanding of screening results may be crucial to adherence to follow-up lung cancer screening.
7.3: Patient understanding of anticipated follow-up may be crucial to adherence to follow-up lung cancer screening.
7.4: The study's objective is to determine patient factors associated with the identification of follow-up recommendations.
7.5: The study aims to use the identification of follow-up recommendations as a measure of patient understanding of screening results after lung cancer screening.
7.6: The study aims to determine whether misidentification of follow-up recommendations is associated with lower adherence to follow-up recommendations.
7.7: The study was a prospective study.
7.8: The study involved patients in the University of Washington/Seattle Cancer Care Alliance lung cancer screening registry.
7.9: Patients underwent an initial lung cancer screening examination between June 2017 and September 2019.
7.10: Potential participants were mailed a survey after the initial lung cancer screening examination.
7.11: Additional data were abstracted from the electronic health record for the study.
7.12: Additional data were abstracted from the lung cancer screening registry for the study.
7.13: Participants were asked to identify the timing for their follow-up.
7.14: Participants were asked to identify the next step for their follow-up.
7.15: The answers provided by participants were to correspond to the lung imaging reporting and data system recommendations.
7.16: The study examined associations between incorrect identification of recommended follow-up and patient-level characteristics.
7.17: The study examined associations between incorrect identification of recommended follow-up and self-perceived benefit/harm of lung cancer screening.
7.18: The study examined associations between incorrect identification of recommended follow-up and lung cancer screening knowledge.
7.19: The study examined associations between incorrect identification of recommended follow-up and Lung-RADS score.
7.20: The study examined associations between incorrect identification of recommended follow-up and the patient-reported method of lung cancer screening results communication.
7.21: Multivariable logistic regression was used to evaluate associations with incorrect identification of recommendations.
7.22: The study assessed incorrect identification of recommendations as a potential mechanism for poor adherence using a separate regression model.
7.23: One hundred eighty-eight participants completed the survey.
7.24: The survey had a response rate of 44%.
7.25: Forty-seven percent of participants misidentified their follow-up recommendation.
7.26: Participants with Lung-RADS scores ≥3 had higher odds of incorrectly identifying follow-up recommendations than those with scores <3.
7.27: Participants with lower educational attainment had higher odds of incorrectly identifying follow-up recommendations than those with higher educational attainment.
7.28: There was no significant association between incorrect identification of follow-up recommendations and ultimate adherence to follow-up.
7.29: Understanding of lung cancer screening follow-up appears to be poor.
7.30: Understanding of lung cancer screening follow-up appears to be particularly poor among those with lower education levels.
7.31: Understanding of lung cancer screening follow-up appears to be particularly poor among those with positive findings.
7.32: Among survey responders, incorrect identification of follow-up was not associated with poor adherence.
7.33: The lack of association between incorrect identification of follow-up and poor adherence suggests that other factors may be driving adherence behavior.
7.34: Provider interventions are a potential factor that may be driving adherence behavior.
7.35: The results of the study can inform efforts to target improved patient education regarding follow-up for lung cancer screening.

8.1: Lung cancer screening is effective in reducing mortality.
8.2: The effectiveness of lung cancer screening in reducing mortality is particularly high when patients adhere to follow-up recommendations standardized by Lung-RADS.
8.3: Patient adherence to recommended screening intervals varies.
8.4: Variation in patient adherence to recommended screening intervals can potentially diminish the benefit of lung cancer screening.
8.5: A systematic review and meta-analysis were conducted to study patient adherence to Lung-RADS-recommended screening intervals.
8.6: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials were systematically searched.
8.7: Major radiology and oncology conference archives were systematically searched between April 28, 2014, and December 17, 2020.
8.8: Eligible studies mentioned patient adherence to Lung-RADS recommendations.
8.9: The review protocol was registered with PROSPERO under the identifier CRD42020189326.
8.10: 24 eligible studies were identified for qualitative summary.
8.11: 21 of the identified studies were suitable for meta-analysis.
8.12: The pooled adherence rate for defined adherence was 57% with a 95% confidence interval of 46%-69% among 6689 patients.
8.13: Defined adherence refers to an annual incidence screen performed within 15 months.
8.14: The pooled adherence rate for anytime adherence was 65% with a 95% confidence interval of 55%-75% among 5085 patients.
8.15: There was large heterogeneity in adherence rates between studies.

9.1: Lung cancer screening can reduce lung cancer mortality.
9.2: Close follow-up and adherence to management recommendations are necessary to reduce lung cancer mortality through lung cancer screening.
9.3: Little is known about factors associated with adherence to lung cancer screening in real-world practice.
9.4: Data on adherence to lung cancer screening in real-world practice is limited to case series from selected lung cancer screening programs.
9.5: The study aimed to analyze adherence to follow-up based on standardized follow-up recommendations in a national cohort.
9.6: The study aimed to identify factors associated with delayed or absent follow-up in a national cohort.
9.7: The study was a retrospective cohort study.
9.8: The study was conducted in Veterans Health Administration facilities across the US.
9.9: Veterans were screened for lung cancer between 2015 to 2019.
9.10: The screening involved sufficient follow-up time for veterans to receive recommended evaluation.
9.11: Logistic regression analyses were performed at the patient level.
9.12: Logistic regression analyses were performed at the facility level.
9.13: Data for the study were analyzed from November 26, 2019, to December 16, 2020.
9.14: The study evaluated the receipt of the recommended next step after initial lung cancer screening according to the Lung CT Screening Reporting & Data System category.
9.15: The receipt of follow-up was captured in Veterans Health Administration or Medicare claims.
9.18: The mean age of veterans was 65.2 years with a standard deviation of 5.5 years.
9.19: 17,863 veterans (63.1%) underwent recommended follow-up within the expected timeframe.
9.22: Facility-level differences were associated with 9.2% of the observed variation in rates of late evaluation.
9.23: Facility-level differences were associated with 9.2% of the observed variation in rates of absent evaluation.
9.24: In multivariable-adjusted models, Black veterans had an odds ratio of 1.19 for delayed or no follow-up compared to others, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.10-1.29.
9.25: Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder had an odds ratio of 1.13 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.03-1.23.
9.26: Veterans with substance use disorders had an odds ratio of 1.11 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.01-1.22.
9.27: Veterans with lower income had an odds ratio of 0.88 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 0.79-0.98.
9.28: Veterans living at a greater distance from a Veterans Health Administration facility had an odds ratio of 1.06 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.02-1.10.
9.29: Veterans with higher risk findings (Lung-RADS category 4 vs Lung-RADS category 1) had an odds ratio of 0.35 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 0.28-0.43.
9.30: Veterans screened in high lung cancer screening volume facilities had an odds ratio of 0.38 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 0.21-0.67.
9.31: Veterans screened in academic facilities had an odds ratio of 0.86 for delayed or no follow-up, with a 95% confidence interval of 0.80-0.92.
9.32: In sensitivity analyses, the expected evaluation ranged from 14,486 veterans (49.7%) under stringent definitions of adherence to follow-up.
9.33: Under liberal definitions of adherence, the expected evaluation ranged to 20,578 veterans (78.8%).
9.34: In this cohort study, follow-up care was captured from the integrated Veterans Health Administration health care system and Medicare.
9.35: Less than two-thirds of patients received timely recommended follow-up after initial lung cancer screening.
9.36: Marginalized populations, such as Black individuals, individuals with mental health disorders, and individuals with low income, were at higher risk of delayed or absent follow-up.
9.37: Marginalized populations have long experienced disparities in lung cancer outcomes.
9.38: Future work should focus on identifying facilities that promote high adherence to lung cancer screening follow-up.
9.39: There is a need to disseminate successful strategies to promote equity in lung cancer screening among marginalized populations.

10.1: Racial disparities in accessing clinically appropriate, advanced diagnostic imaging have not been well studied.
10.2: Socioeconomic disparities in accessing clinically appropriate, advanced diagnostic imaging have not been well studied.
10.3: The study assesses the relationship between demographic factors and the incidence of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.4: The study assesses the relationship between socioeconomic factors and the incidence of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.5: A retrospective review of outpatient CT and MRI appointments was performed at a quaternary academic medical center and affiliated outpatient facilities.
10.6: The retrospective review covered a 12-month period.
10.7: Missed appointments not rescheduled in advance were classified as imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.10: Univariate analyses were performed to determine if demographic factors were predictive of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.11: Univariate analyses were performed to determine if socioeconomic factors were predictive of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.12: Multivariate analyses were performed to determine if demographic factors were predictive of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.13: Multivariate analyses were performed to determine if socioeconomic factors were predictive of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.15: The 57,847 patients represented 89,943 scheduled unique imaging appointments.
10.16: 5,840 (6.1%) of the 89,943 scheduled unique imaging appointments were imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.17: 0.8% of imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) appointments had low appropriateness scores.
10.18: 1.2% of completed appointments had low appropriateness scores.
10.19: There is a statistical significance in the appropriateness scores between imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs) and completed appointments (P < .01).
10.20: Appointments covered by commercial insurance had a 5.2% rate of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.21: Appointments covered by Medicare had a 6.3% rate of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.22: Appointments covered by Medicaid had a 14.5% rate of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.23: Appointments covered by self-pay had a 12.0% rate of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.24: Appointments covered by commercial insurance had a significantly lower rate of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs) than those covered by Medicare, Medicaid, and self-pay (P < .05).
10.25: Noncommercial insurance is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.7-2.6.
10.26: Being African American is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.8.
10.27: Being Hispanic is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.2.
10.28: Being of a race other than African American or Hispanic is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.1.
10.29: Speaking a language other than English or Spanish is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.2.
10.30: Being male is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.2.
10.31: Being aged ≥ 65 is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 0.71.
10.32: Having a median household income of a patient home zip code <$50,000 is an independent predictor of a patient having ≥ 1 imaging missed care opportunity (IMCO) with an odds ratio of 1.4.
10.33: Race is an independent predictor of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.34: Socioeconomic status is an independent predictor of imaging missed care opportunities (IMCOs).
10.35: Radiologists should be aware of the impact of race on access to clinically appropriate advanced diagnostic imaging to enhance patient engagement.
10.36: Radiologists should be aware of the impact of socioeconomic status on access to clinically appropriate advanced diagnostic imaging to enhance patient engagement.

11.1: For individuals who have smoked fewer than 100 cigarettes in their lifetime, lung cancer has become an important health issue.
11.2: The study aimed to investigate the effects of changes in the prevalence of tobacco smoking on lung cancer.
11.3: The study aimed to investigate the effects of changes in particulate matter (PM) 2.5 levels on lung cancer.
11.4: The study reviewed 371,084 patients with lung cancer to assess smoking prevalence.
11.5: The study reviewed 371,084 patients with lung cancer to assess correlations between the incidence of adenocarcinoma lung cancer and non-adenocarcinoma lung cancer.
11.6: Two subsets were selected to assess different trends in adenocarcinoma lung cancer stages.
11.7: Two subsets were selected to assess the effect of particulate matter (PM) on adenocarcinoma lung cancer stages.
11.8: The proportion of male adult ever-smokers decreased from 59.4% to 29.9% from 1995 to 2015.
11.9: The female smoking rate remained low, changing from 3.2% to 5.3% from 1995 to 2015.
11.10: Adenocarcinoma lung cancer incidence in males increased from 9.06 to 23.25 per 100,000 population.
11.11: Adenocarcinoma lung cancer incidence in females increased from 7.05 to 24.22 per 100,000 population.
11.12: Atmospheric visibility in NT improved from 7.6 km to 11.5 km since 1993.
11.13: Atmospheric visibility in ST deteriorated from 16.3 km to 4.2 km since 1993.
11.14: The annual percent change in adenocarcinoma lung cancer stages IB to IV in NT was 0.3% since 2009, with a 95% confidence interval of -1.9% to 2.6%.
11.15: The annual percent change in adenocarcinoma lung cancer stages IB to IV in ST was 4.6% since 2007, with a 95% confidence interval of 3.3% to 5.8%.
11.16: 53% of patients with lung cancer had never smoked.
11.17: The five-year survival rate for never-smokers with adenocarcinoma lung cancer was 12.6% in NT and 4.5% in ST.
11.18: The five-year survival rate for patients with EGFR wild-type genes with adenocarcinoma lung cancer was 12.6% in NT and 4.5% in ST.
11.19: The five-year survival rate for female patients with adenocarcinoma lung cancer was 12.6% in NT and 4.5% in ST.
11.20: The hazard ratio for five-year survival in NT compared to ST was 0.79, with a 95% confidence interval of 0.70 to 0.90.
11.21: In Taiwan, more than 50% of patients with lung cancer had never smoked.

viewpoints: Lung cancer screening faces a challenge of low screening rate, which is less than 10%.
Lung cancer screening faces a challenge of high false-positive rate.
Lung cancer screening faces a challenge of sub-optimal workflows due to inadequate patient management.
Lung cancer screening faces a challenge of under-utilization of multimodal data.
Lung cancer screening faces a challenge of a global shortage of radiologists.

sentences.sentence: Hence, there is an important and immediate need for multidisciplinary efforts to broadly, equitably, and optimally implement LCS for minimized lung cancer mortality [12].

12.1: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality in the United States.
12.2: Lung cancer screening with low-dose CT reduces mortality among high-risk current and former smokers.
12.3: Lung cancer screening with low-dose CT has been covered by public insurers without cost sharing since 2015.
12.4: Lung cancer screening with low-dose CT has been covered by private insurers without cost sharing since 2015.
12.5: Patients confront numerous barriers to participation in lung cancer screening.
12.6: Referring providers confront numerous barriers to participation in lung cancer screening.
12.7: Radiologists must be knowledgeable of the barriers to participation in lung cancer screening to best serve in multidisciplinary efforts to expand lung cancer screening nationwide.
12.8: A better understanding of the difficulties confronted by other stakeholders in lung cancer screening will help radiologists continue to collaboratively guide the growth of lung cancer screening programs in their communities.
12.9: The article reviews barriers to participation in lung cancer screening for patients.
12.10: The article reviews barriers to participation in lung cancer screening for referring providers.
12.11: The article reviews possible solutions to barriers to participation in lung cancer screening.
12.12: The article reviews interventions currently underway to address barriers to participation in lung cancer screening.

viewpoints: There is an important and immediate need for multidisciplinary efforts to implement lung cancer screening broadly.
There is an important and immediate need for multidisciplinary efforts to implement lung cancer screening equitably.
There is an important and immediate need for multidisciplinary efforts to implement lung cancer screening optimally to minimize lung cancer mortality.

sentences.sentence: Artificial intelligence (AI) promises to improve the quality and efficiency of LCS significantly.
viewpoints: Artificial intelligence promises to significantly improve the quality of lung cancer screening.
Artificial intelligence promises to significantly improve the efficiency of lung cancer screening.

sentences.sentence: In particular, there is a vast amount of multimodal data accumulated over the past years, including low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) images, patient demographics, smoking history, disease history, family cancer history, pathological results, follow-up data, etc. [2]
viewpoints: There is a vast amount of multimodal data accumulated over the past years related to lung cancer screening.
The multimodal data accumulated includes low-dose computed tomography images.
The multimodal data accumulated includes patient demographics.
The multimodal data accumulated includes smoking history.
The multimodal data accumulated includes disease history.
The multimodal data accumulated includes family cancer history.
The multimodal data accumulated includes pathological results.
The multimodal data accumulated includes follow-up data.

sentences.sentence: LCS involves multiple clinical tasks, including lung nodule detection and characterization, Lung-RADS-based patient follow-up management, lung cancer risk estimation, and significant incidental findings such as diagnosis of various pulmonary, cardiovascular, and chest abnormalities.
viewpoints: Lung cancer screening involves the clinical task of lung nodule detection.
Lung cancer screening involves the clinical task of lung nodule characterization.
Lung cancer screening involves the clinical task of Lung-RADS-based patient follow-up management.
Lung cancer screening involves the clinical task of lung cancer risk estimation.
Lung cancer screening involves diagnosing significant incidental findings, such as various pulmonary abnormalities.
Lung cancer screening involves diagnosing significant incidental findings, such as various cardiovascular abnormalities.
Lung cancer screening involves diagnosing significant incidental findings, such as various chest abnormalities.

sentences.sentence: Deep learning methods achieved promising results for LCS-related tasks.
viewpoints: Deep learning methods have achieved promising results for lung cancer screening-related tasks.

sentences.sentence: For example, a deep learning method was proposed for lung cancer detection and risk estimation with LDCT in an end-to-end manner [13].

13.1: In 2018, an estimated 160,000 deaths were caused by lung cancer in the United States.
13.2: Lung cancer is the most common cause of cancer death in the United States.

viewpoints: A deep learning method was proposed for lung cancer detection with low-dose computed tomography in an end-to-end manner.
A deep learning method was proposed for lung cancer risk estimation with low-dose computed tomography in an end-to-end manner.

sentences.sentence: Recently, the Sybil model [14] was developed for lung cancer risk prediction using a single LDCT scan.

14.1: Low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening is effective.
14.2: Most eligible people are not being screened with low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer.
14.3: Tools providing personalized future cancer risk assessment can help focus screening approaches on individuals most likely to benefit.
14.4: A deep learning model could be built to assess the entire volumetric low-dose computed tomography data to predict individual risk.
14.5: The deep learning model could predict individual risk without requiring additional demographic data.
14.6: The deep learning model could predict individual risk without requiring additional clinical data.
14.7: A model called Sybil was developed using low-dose computed tomographies from the National Lung Screening Trial.
14.8: Sybil requires only one low-dose computed tomography scan.
14.9: Sybil does not require clinical data.
14.10: Sybil does not require radiologist annotations.
14.11: Sybil can run in real time in the background on a radiology reading station.
14.12: Sybil was validated on a heldout set of 6,282 low-dose computed tomographies from National Lung Screening Trial participants.
14.13: Sybil was validated on 8,821 low-dose computed tomographies from Massachusetts General Hospital.
14.14: Sybil was validated on 12,280 low-dose computed tomographies from Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
14.15: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital data included people with a range of smoking history, including nonsmokers.
14.16: Sybil achieved an area under the receiver-operator curve of 0.92 for lung cancer prediction at 1 year on National Lung Screening Trial validation set.
14.17: Sybil achieved an area under the receiver-operator curve of 0.86 for lung cancer prediction at 1 year on Massachusetts General Hospital validation set.
14.18: Sybil achieved an area under the receiver-operator curve of 0.94 for lung cancer prediction at 1 year on Chang Gung Memorial Hospital validation set.
14.19: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.75 on National Lung Screening Trial validation set.
14.20: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.81 on Massachusetts General Hospital validation set.
14.21: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.80 on Chang Gung Memorial Hospital validation set.
14.22: Sybil can accurately predict an individual's future lung cancer risk from a single low-dose computed tomography scan.
14.23: Sybil can further enable personalized screening.
14.24: Future study is required to understand Sybil's clinical applications.
14.25: The model Sybil and its annotations are publicly available.

viewpoints: The Sybil model was developed for lung cancer risk prediction using a single low-dose computed tomography scan.

sentences.sentence: In several studies [15], [16], deep learning models were developed for cardiovascular diseases (CVD) risk prediction with LDCT from LCS.

15.1: Lung cancer screening by low-dose computed tomography offers an opportunity to impact lung cancer mortality through detection of coronary artery calcification.
15.2: Lung cancer screening by low-dose computed tomography offers an opportunity to impact coronary heart disease mortality through detection of coronary artery calcification.
15.3: The value of coronary artery calcification detection in lung cancer screening participants in the Lung Screen Uptake Trial is explored.
15.4: The value of cardiovascular disease risk assessment in lung cancer screening participants in the Lung Screen Uptake Trial is explored.
15.5: Current smokers aged 60-75 were invited to a 'lung health check' in this cross-sectional study.
15.6: Ex-smokers aged 60-75 were invited to a 'lung health check' in this cross-sectional study.
15.7: Data collection included a cardiovascular disease risk assessment.
15.8: The cardiovascular disease risk assessment enabled estimation of 10-year cardiovascular disease risk using the QRISK2 score.
15.9: Participants meeting the required lung cancer risk underwent an ungated, non-contrast low-dose computed tomography.
15.12: A multivariate analysis of predictors of statin use is presented.
15.13: 680 individuals were included in the final analysis out of 1005 enrolled.
15.14: 421 individuals (61.9%) had coronary artery calcification present.
15.15: 49 individuals (7.2%) had heavy coronary artery calcification.
15.16: 668 participants (98%) had a QRISK2 score of 10% or higher.
15.17: QRISK2 score was positively associated with increasing coronary artery calcification grade.
15.18: The odds ratio for QRISK2=10%-20% was 4.29 (confidence interval 0.93 to 19.88) for increasing coronary artery calcification grade.
15.19: The odds ratio for QRISK2≥20% was 12.29 (confidence interval 2.68 to 56.1) for increasing coronary artery calcification grade.
15.20: 56.8% of those who qualified for statin primary prevention (QRISK2≥10%) did not report a history of statin use.
15.21: In the multivariate analysis, statin use was associated with age.
15.22: In the multivariate analysis, statin use was associated with body mass index.
15.23: In the multivariate analysis, statin use was associated with a history of hypertension.
15.24: In the multivariate analysis, statin use was associated with a history of diabetes.
15.25: Lung cancer screening offers an important opportunity for instituting cardiovascular disease risk assessment in all lung cancer screening participants.
15.26: Instituting cardiovascular disease risk assessment in lung cancer screening participants is beneficial irrespective of the presence of low-dose computed tomography-detected coronary artery calcification.
15.27: Further studies are needed to determine whether coronary artery calcification could enhance uptake of primary preventative strategies.
15.28: Further studies are needed to determine whether coronary artery calcification could enhance adherence to primary preventative strategies.

16.1: Cancer patients have a higher risk of cardiovascular disease mortality compared to the general population.
16.2: Low dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening offers an opportunity for CVD risk estimation.
16.3: Low dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening can be used for simultaneous CVD risk estimation in at-risk patients.
16.4: The deep learning CVD risk prediction model is trained with 30,286 LDCTs from the National Lung Cancer Screening Trial.
16.5: The deep learning CVD risk prediction model achieves an area under the curve of 0.871 on a test set of 2,085 subjects.
16.6: The deep learning CVD risk prediction model identifies patients with high CVD mortality risks with an area under the curve of 0.768.
16.7: The deep learning CVD risk prediction model is validated against ECG-gated cardiac CT based markers.
16.8: The ECG-gated cardiac CT based markers include the coronary artery calcification score.
16.9: The ECG-gated cardiac CT based markers include the CAD-RADS score.
16.10: The ECG-gated cardiac CT based markers include the MESA 10-year risk score.
16.11: The validation uses an independent dataset of 335 subjects.
16.12: In high-risk patients, deep learning can convert low dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening into a dual-screening quantitative tool.
16.13: The dual-screening quantitative tool can be used for CVD risk estimation.

viewpoints: Deep learning models were developed for cardiovascular diseases risk prediction using low-dose computed tomography from lung cancer screening.

sentences.sentence: Although promising, these LCS-related AI models were developed with relatively small single-modality datasets for individual tasks, limiting their performance and utility in the multitask LCS workflow.
viewpoints: Although promising, lung cancer screening-related AI models were developed with relatively small single-modality datasets for individual tasks.
The small single-modality datasets limit the performance of lung cancer screening-related AI models in the multitask lung cancer screening workflow.
The small single-modality datasets limit the utility of lung cancer screening-related AI models in the multitask lung cancer screening workflow.

sentences.sentence: Additionally, the training schemes of current lung cancer risk models [13], [14] require costly bounding box annotations, which makes building large-scale training datasets infeasible.

13.1: In 2018, an estimated 160,000 deaths were caused by lung cancer in the United States.
13.2: Lung cancer is the most common cause of cancer death in the United States.

14.1: Low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening is effective.
14.2: Most eligible people are not being screened with low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer.

14.4: A deep learning model could be built to assess the entire volumetric low-dose computed tomography data to predict individual risk.
14.5: The deep learning model could predict individual risk without requiring additional demographic data.
14.6: The deep learning model could predict individual risk without requiring additional clinical data.
14.7: A model called Sybil was developed using low-dose computed tomographies from the National Lung Screening Trial.
14.8: Sybil requires only one low-dose computed tomography scan.
14.9: Sybil does not require clinical data.
14.10: Sybil does not require radiologist annotations.
14.11: Sybil can run in real time in the background on a radiology reading station.

14.13: Sybil was validated on 8,821 low-dose computed tomographies from Massachusetts General Hospital.
14.14: Sybil was validated on 12,280 low-dose computed tomographies from Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.

14.17: Sybil achieved an area under the receiver-operator curve of 0.86 for lung cancer prediction at 1 year on Massachusetts General Hospital validation set.
14.18: Sybil achieved an area under the receiver-operator curve of 0.94 for lung cancer prediction at 1 year on Chang Gung Memorial Hospital validation set.
14.19: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.75 on National Lung Screening Trial validation set.
14.20: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.81 on Massachusetts General Hospital validation set.
14.21: Concordance index for Sybil over 6 years was 0.80 on Chang Gung Memorial Hospital validation set.
14.22: Sybil can accurately predict an individual's future lung cancer risk from a single low-dose computed tomography scan.

viewpoints: The training schemes of current lung cancer risk models require costly bounding box annotations.
The requirement for costly bounding box annotations makes building large-scale training datasets infeasible.

sentences.sentence: In the fast-evolving AI field, foundation models (FMs) have shown previously unseen abilities to understand diverse data types and execute many tasks in a unified fashion [17].
viewpoints: Foundation models in AI have shown previously unseen abilities to understand diverse data types.
Foundation models in AI have shown previously unseen abilities to execute many tasks in a unified fashion.

sentences.sentence: Large FMs have updated the state-of-the-art (SoTA) performance across a wide range of tasks, such as natural language processing [18], [19], [20], computer vision [21], [22], and multimodal understanding [23], [24], [25].
viewpoints: Large foundation models have updated the state-of-the-art performance in natural language processing.
Large foundation models have updated the state-of-the-art performance in computer vision.
Large foundation models have updated the state-of-the-art performance in multimodal understanding.

sentences.sentence: Inspired by these breakthroughs, increasing efforts have been made to develop medical foundation models, such as biomedical language models [26], [27], [28], [29], [30], [31], medical vision-language models [32], [33], [34], and generalist medical AI models [35], [36], [37].

35.1: The development of highly flexible, reusable AI models is exceptionally rapid.
35.2: Highly flexible, reusable AI models are likely to usher in newfound capabilities in medicine.
35.3: A new paradigm for medical AI is proposed, referred to as generalist medical AI (GMAI).
35.4: GMAI models will be capable of carrying out a diverse set of tasks.
35.5: GMAI models will require very little or no task-specific labelled data to carry out tasks.
35.6: GMAI models are built through self-supervision on large, diverse datasets.
35.7: GMAI will flexibly interpret different combinations of medical modalities.
35.8: Medical modalities for GMAI include data from imaging, electronic health records, laboratory results, genomics, graphs, or medical text.
35.9: GMAI models will produce expressive outputs.
35.10: Expressive outputs of GMAI models include free-text explanations, spoken recommendations, or image annotations.
35.11: Expressive outputs of GMAI models demonstrate advanced medical reasoning abilities.
35.12: A set of high-impact potential applications for GMAI is identified.
35.13: Specific technical capabilities necessary to enable high-impact potential applications for GMAI are laid out.
35.14: Specific training datasets necessary to enable high-impact potential applications for GMAI are laid out.
35.15: GMAI-enabled applications are expected to challenge current strategies for regulating AI devices for medicine.
35.16: GMAI-enabled applications are expected to challenge current strategies for validating AI devices for medicine.
35.17: GMAI-enabled applications are expected to shift practices associated with the collection of large medical datasets.

viewpoints: Inspired by breakthroughs in AI foundation models, increasing efforts have been made to develop medical foundation models.
Increasing efforts have been made to develop biomedical language models.
Increasing efforts have been made to develop medical vision-language models.
Increasing efforts have been made to develop generalist medical AI models.

sentences.sentence: However, none of the existing FMs can effectively perform a variety of LCS tasks by interpreting the multimodal clinical data associated with LCS, particularly three-dimensional (3D) LDCT scans.
viewpoints: None of the existing foundation models can effectively perform a variety of lung cancer screening tasks by interpreting multimodal clinical data associated with lung cancer screening.
None of the existing foundation models can effectively interpret three-dimensional low-dose computed tomography scans for lung cancer screening tasks.

sentences.sentence: This limitation is primarily due to challenges in data curation and model architecture.
viewpoints: The limitation of foundation models in performing lung cancer screening tasks is primarily due to challenges in data curation.
The limitation of foundation models in performing lung cancer screening tasks is primarily due to challenges in model architecture.

sentences.sentence: First, there is a high bar to systematically curate large-scale multimodal multitask datasets obtained in the real-world LCS workflow.
viewpoints: There is a high bar to systematically curate large-scale multimodal multitask datasets obtained in the real-world lung cancer screening workflow.

sentences.sentence: Extensive domain-specific expertise and efforts are required to query, preprocess, and align 3D medical images and diverse structured/unstructured text-based clinical data with LCS-related tasks.
viewpoints: Extensive domain-specific expertise is required to query 3D medical images and diverse clinical data for lung cancer screening tasks.
Extensive domain-specific expertise is required to preprocess 3D medical images and diverse clinical data for lung cancer screening tasks.
Extensive domain-specific expertise is required to align 3D medical images and diverse clinical data with lung cancer screening tasks.

sentences.sentence: Second, there is no scalable and adaptable foundation model dedicated to effectively interpreting multimodal LCS data, especially 3D CT images at different scales, and effectively performing diverse LCS-related tasks.
viewpoints: There is no scalable and adaptable foundation model dedicated to effectively interpreting multimodal lung cancer screening data.
There is no scalable and adaptable foundation model dedicated to effectively interpreting 3D CT images at different scales for lung cancer screening.
There is no scalable and adaptable foundation model dedicated to effectively performing diverse lung cancer screening-related tasks.

sentences.sentence: Due to the high dimensionality of volumetric CT images, existing efforts only used small 2D/3D convolutional neural networks [38] and small vision Transformer models [39] at affordable computational costs.
viewpoints: Due to the high dimensionality of volumetric CT images, existing efforts have only used small 2D/3D convolutional neural networks.
Due to the high dimensionality of volumetric CT images, existing efforts have only used small vision Transformer models.
Small 2D/3D convolutional neural networks and small vision Transformer models are used at affordable computational costs.

sentences.sentence: In this work, we present an integrated and scalable data curation approach to align high-dimensional medical images with other clinical datasets for LCS-related tasks, including 17 LCS workflow-related tasks and 49 data elements.
viewpoints: An integrated and scalable data curation approach is presented to align high-dimensional medical images with other clinical datasets for lung cancer screening-related tasks.
The data curation approach addresses 17 lung cancer screening workflow-related tasks.
The data curation approach involves 49 data elements.

sentences.sentence: Then, we develop a Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) that perceives multimodal data including 3D CT volumes and various other clinical data, and performs multiple tasks involved in the LCS workflow.
viewpoints: A Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) is developed to perceive multimodal data including 3D CT volumes.
The Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) is developed to perceive various other clinical data.
The Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) is developed to perform multiple tasks involved in the lung cancer screening workflow.

sentences.sentence: Figure 1 illustrates the M3FM architecture, along with its training and inference processes.
viewpoints: Figure 1 illustrates the Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) architecture.
Figure 1 illustrates the training process of the Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM).
Figure 1 illustrates the inference process of the Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM).

sentences.sentence: Extensive experiments show that our M3FM outperforms the previous SoTA models through large-scale multimodal and multitask learning, with the ability to identify informative data elements and adapt to the out-of-distribution task with a small dataset.
viewpoints: Extensive experiments show that the Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) outperforms previous state-of-the-art models through large-scale multimodal learning.
Extensive experiments show that the Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) outperforms previous state-of-the-art models through multitask learning.
The Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) has the ability to identify informative data elements.
The Medical Multimodal Multitask Foundation Model (M3FM) can adapt to out-of-distribution tasks with a small dataset.

sentences.sentence: Fig. 1: Overview of medical multimodal multitask foundation model (M3FM).
viewpoints: Fig. 1 provides an overview of the medical multimodal multitask foundation model (M3FM).

sentences.sentence: a M3FM architecture consists of four components: Computed Tomography Vision Transformer (CTViT), Text Transformer, Task Encoder, and Predictors.
viewpoints: The M3FM architecture consists of four components: Computed Tomography Vision Transformer (CTViT), Text Transformer, Task Encoder, and Predictors.

sentences.sentence: b Pretraining CTViT on multiscale CT volumes with voxel size-aware masked image modeling.
viewpoints: CTViT is pretrained on multiscale CT volumes.
Pretraining of CTViT uses voxel size-aware masked image modeling.

sentences.sentence: Scale 1, Scale 2, ⋯ , and Scale S denote S different sizes of images.
viewpoints: Scale 1, Scale 2, ⋯ , and Scale S denote S different sizes of images.

sentences.sentence: c Pretraining Text Transformer with masked image models, where T1, T2, ⋯ , and T5 denote a sequence of text tokens, T1, T2, and T4 are inputs, T3 and T5 are targets, and MASK is a special token meaning that the input token is masked.
viewpoints: The Text Transformer is pretrained with masked image models.
T1, T2, ⋯ , and T5 denote a sequence of text tokens during the pretraining of the Text Transformer.
In the pretraining of the Text Transformer, T1, T2, and T4 are inputs.
In the pretraining of the Text Transformer, T3 and T5 are targets.
MASK is a special token meaning that the input token is masked in the pretraining of the Text Transformer.

sentences.sentence: d Training the shared M3FM jointly with flexible multimodal and synergistic multitask learning using our distributed task-parallel strategy.
viewpoints: The shared M3FM is trained jointly with flexible multimodal learning.
The shared M3FM is trained jointly with synergistic multitask learning.
Training uses a distributed task-parallel strategy.

sentences.sentence: Each device focuses on a single task with task-specific inputs, targets, and loss functions.
viewpoints: Each device focuses on a single task in the distributed task-parallel strategy.
Each device uses task-specific inputs, targets, and loss functions.

sentences.sentence: D , N , and R denote the numbers of different devices, tasks, and image regions, respectively.
viewpoints: D denotes the number of different devices.
N denotes the number of tasks.
R denotes the number of image regions.

sentences.sentence: Different tasks may have the same multimodal inputs on devices 1 and 2 and various multimodal or single-modality inputs on devices 2, 3, 4, and 5.
viewpoints: Different tasks may have the same multimodal inputs on devices 1 and 2.
Different tasks may have various multimodal or single-modality inputs on devices 2, 3, 4, and 5.

sentences.sentence: e M3FM inference flexibly handles multi-scale CT volumes (indicated by the rectangle boxes in different sizes and colors), clinical data, and multiple tasks.
viewpoints: M3FM inference flexibly handles multi-scale CT volumes.
Multi-scale CT volumes are indicated by rectangle boxes in different sizes and colors.
M3FM inference flexibly handles clinical data.
M3FM inference flexibly handles multiple tasks.

sentences.sentence: The colors of the CT bounding boxes match those of the questions and the predicted answers.
viewpoints: The colors of the CT bounding boxes match those of the questions.
The colors of the CT bounding boxes match those of the predicted answers.

sentences.sentence: For example, to answer Question 16, M3FM takes the orange region in the CT volume automatically localized using an organ localization model, the corresponding voxel size, and clinical text data as inputs.
viewpoints: To answer Question 16, M3FM takes the orange region in the CT volume using an organ localization model as input.
To answer Question 16, M3FM takes the corresponding voxel size as input.
To answer Question 16, M3FM takes clinical text data as input.
The orange region in the CT volume is automatically localized using an organ localization model.

sentences.sentence: Questions 17 and 18 are two examples of auxiliary information retrieval tasks for clinical data modeling, which only take the clinical text as input.
viewpoints: Questions 17 and 18 are examples of auxiliary information retrieval tasks for clinical data modeling.
Auxiliary information retrieval tasks for clinical data modeling, such as Questions 17 and 18, only take the clinical text as input.

sentences.sentence: Question 19 predicts the Lung CT Screening Reporting and Data System (Lung-RADS) from lung nodule descriptions in a radiology report.
viewpoints: Question 19 predicts the Lung CT Screening Reporting and Data System (Lung-RADS).
Lung-RADS is predicted from lung nodule descriptions in a radiology report.
